verses.text: So the king and Haman came to have wine with Queen Esther.
verses.comment: The narrative resumes with the king and Haman attending Esther's banquet. Hospitality and feasting play a significant role in the way God’s providence unfolds in the story.

verses.text: On the second day, as they drank wine, the king again said to Esther, 'What is your petition, Queen Esther? It shall be granted you. And what is your request? Even up to half the kingdom, it will be done!'
verses.comment: The king's promise here demonstrates trust and favor toward Esther. The repeating of the offer shows the seriousness of the king’s willingness to act, echoing themes of royal authority and intercession.

verses.text: Then Queen Esther answered, 'If I have found favor in your eyes, O king, and if it pleases the king, let my life be granted me as my petition, and my people as my request.'
verses.comment: Esther humbly frames her request, aligning her fate with that of her people—demonstrating mediation and advocacy, reminiscent of biblical figures who intercede for their people (see Ex. 32:11-14).

verses.text: For we have been sold, I and my people, to be destroyed, killed, and annihilated. If we had only been sold as male and female slaves, I would have held my peace, for our trouble would not be worth troubling the king.'
verses.comment: By referencing 'being sold,' Esther alludes to Haman's bribe for the destruction of the Jews (Esth. 3:9). Her reasoning highlights a deep selflessness and concern for others—foreshadowing later patterns of self-sacrifice.

verses.text: King Ahasuerus said to Queen Esther, 'Who is he, and where is he, who has presumed to do this?'
verses.comment: The king’s indignation sets the stage for revelation and justice—showing that the righteous ruler will inquire into, and act upon, injustice.

verses.text: And Esther said, 'A foe and enemy! This wicked Haman.' Then Haman was terrified before the king and queen.
verses.comment: Esther’s boldness in naming Haman as the enemy reveals the courage needed to confront evil. Her intercessory role underscores the call to speak truth before rulers, which finds a spiritual parallel in Christians’ ministry and witness.

verses.text: The king rose in his anger from drinking wine and went into the palace garden, but Haman stayed to beg for his life from Queen Esther, for he saw that evil was determined against him by the king.
verses.comment: Haman’s desperate appeal to Esther, rather than the king, shows his recognition that mercy may be found through intercession. This hints at the spiritual value of seeking mediation with those close to the sovereign.

verses.text: When the king returned from the palace garden to the place of the wine drinking, Haman was falling on the couch where Esther was. The king said, 'Will he even assault the queen in my presence, in my own house?' As the word left the king's mouth, they covered Haman's face.
verses.comment: Covering Haman’s face marks his condemnation. The scene illustrates that judgment is executed swiftly upon the unrepentant enemy.

verses.text: Then Harbona, one of the eunuchs in attendance on the king, said, 'Behold, the gallows, fifty cubits high, which Haman made for Mordecai, whose word saved the king, stands at Haman's house.' And the king said, 'Hang him on it.'
verses.comment: The irony of Haman’s plot being turned against him reemphasizes the biblical principle that those who dig a pit for others will fall into it themselves (see Ps. 7:15).

verses.text: So they hanged Haman on the gallows he had prepared for Mordecai. Then the king’s anger abated.
verses.comment: Divine justice is accomplished as the enemy’s scheme is reversed, a recurring theme that points symbolically to Christ’s ultimate victory over sin and death (see Rom. 8:28). The narrative also contains a subtle lesson on the importance of mediation, justice, and the authority of those appointed to preserve the community.
